body: Those utm_source and utm_campaign parameters can't hurt. We might be able to separate them in the logs perhaps?

Just realized the importance of having those. 
Yes, not only in the log, we may later implement functionality to track the clicks on the web as well. 
And, ATM there is no effect having them in the URL, it just opens the site with no problem. 
Will add them and update the patch.
That's possible on Linux, though I do not know whether the Windows Launcher is capable to parse the conf-file in that case.

With regard to the multiple licenses: yes the JARs contain source-code from other projects and from my POV this is the problem Justin made us aware of. The Source jars from maven central are also very thin on info about the license. One of the best sources in the end was:

https://github.com/javaee/glassfish/issues/22474

There for jaxb1 the base projects are mentioned and I deduced from the contents of the JARs (packages) and the sources, which licenses need to be applied.
Makes sense. Shouldn't we also create a file under nbbuild/licenses/ ?

That [other solution](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/9/docs/api/java/lang/invoke/MethodHandles.Lookup.html#defineClass-byte:A-) for ```defineClass``` is not a drop in replacement. The arguments differ. Switching the imports is a drop in replacement. I need to check for 9, but exists in 10, ```jdk.internal.misc.Unsafe```

Sure we should, they are part of the PR:
https://github.com/apache/incubator-netbeans/pull/582/files#diff-bbc845541654e749f3a7e6a73be3c0d4
https://github.com/apache/incubator-netbeans/pull/582/files#diff-d9d0cc53823ddc34d10fb690a4833e11

Sorry, I must have scrolled over them.

+1 from me.
Thank you for going through this!
My reading of the config file parser (`/ide/launcher/windows/nblauncher.cpp`) is, that does not allow multiline options (see the use of `fgets` in line 448).
Ok.

It would be great if the commit would hold information, that the author donated the code and where we can find that information. That will prevent needless discussions. It would also be great to document that in the `licenseinfo.xml` file in the `ide.branding` module.
This is a bit different from Code, as for Code the person offering the PR is at most times also the author and thus is a position to donate.
How do you want the commit to hold this information exactly, just say it and we'll do it.

First, it would be great if the author would sign an iCLA.

Then, besides these .png / .gif images we should also get the original file (.psd or whatever it was) because we are certainly going to need more variations. For example, a retina "@2x" variant.

Third, the author should create the PR or at least email the mailing list the files so we have some provenance.

Right now it's not even clear who the author *is*.
PS: I'm -1 on this PR until we clear up the IP.
Yes, of course these things will be done, in the next few days and before merging this.

+1

Note there are more URLs in the file but they could be part of other commits if you want to. The whole `welcome` module might need some tweaks because we have fewer project types now, we don't need an Oracle link, etc.

> That's possible on Linux, though I do not know whether the Windows Launcher is capable to parse the conf-file in that case.
> My reading of the config file parser (/ide/launcher/windows/nblauncher.cpp) is, that does not allow multiline options (see the use of fgets in line 448).

Too bad, it would have made the file more readable imho.

Anyhow, +1 on the PR.
Merging in 24 hours unless objections.

@ebarboni, thanks for testing (and I apologize for belated reply). Seems the build might have been missing some "-static" when building the exe files. I tried to improve that above - could you please try? (Given that it worked for me before, I assume I have a dynamic version of the library installed, so it is difficult for me to be certain if this helped or not, but the exe file is much bigger now, which seems like a good sign.)

Thanks!

Note we already had `-static` in apisupport.harness/windows-launcher-src. My Docker-built exe is ~800KB.

> Regarding sources organization, I think it makes some sense: o.n.bootstrap contains stuff that is platform (i.e. the base launcher); ide contains ide-specific launcher; and apisupport.harness the launcher for custom applications. (There is an unfortunate like from apisupport.harness to ide, which admittedly is a little weird, but otherwise seems to make sense in the modular world.)

I understand the need for one 'generic' launcher and one 'ide' launcher (that perhaps searches for `javac` or whatever).

But why do we have 3 of them?

From what I remember we always had one exe to deal with when doing Platform apps and the only big challenge was changing the .exe icon.

The three launchers are:
-platform base launcher
-IDE launcher
-launcher for platform applications

If the question is if we need separate IDE and application launchers, then there appear to be some differences between these, but I didn't study that in depth.
What does the "platform base launcher" do compared to "launcher for platform applications"?
I've started a discussion in Dev mailing list about updating welcome module. Will move forward with some more pull requests based on the suggestions.
Yes, if you can integrate the new logo into the Welcome screen, that would be great.

I'm afraid we don't have access to logs in netbeans.apache.org, so adding params to the url is of no use.

What we've done in [NETBEANS-330](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NETBEANS-330) is to redirect to http://netbeans-vm.apache.org/ (which in turn redirects to Apache mirrors), I think @jkovalsky  has some root permissions and we can have some statistics if required.

What we could do is to create a link to netbeans-vm.apache.org with appropriate parameters in the Start Page, have them logged in netbeans-vm.apache.org and then redirect to netbeans.apache.org.

Is this sufficient:

https://lists.apache.org/thread.html/d0653563c371df8cfb202571be280bda73253328173cf095c8b3672a@%3Cdev.netbeans.apache.org%3E

> I'm afraid we don't have access to logs in netbeans.apache.org, so adding params to the url is of no use.

Once we make a convenience binary available we can't add that param url afterwards. So it doesn't hurt to have them there.

> Is this sufficient

I have replied on the mailing list. It doesn't seem to identify the artifacts being contributed yet.
The logo and splash screen are mentioned there, yes, and, yes, more details can and will be provided.

@geertjanw I like the way that logo and "Apache NetBeans IDE 9.0" text used in your PR for "splash screen" can I have the source file, so that I can extract the logo and text from it to use in the welcome screen?
I don't have the source file. We're trying to get it from the person who created it.

A way that could be explored is using MR-JARs to be able to expose the same interface, but use different implementations. JDK 8 would be the baseline implementation, implementations for 9,10,11 could be pushed as multi-release enhancements (the support was added with 9).
Seeing agreement, I'll merge.

2. Could David expressly mention the attachments on NETBEANS-851? His email is generic and doesn't mention any particular file/image.

https://lists.apache.org/thread.html/30347fc6ef4f416e36398ba7e37f31cd401396d5377bb5f42bfc72c5@%3Cdev.netbeans.apache.org%3E

I realized that in the case of Maven there is a way to combine CoS-like recompilation and test run (not sure about main class run) into a single tool execution: create an ephemeral POM in a temp dir listing the open projects with snapshot relationships as `<modules>`, then

    mvn resource:copy compiler:compile surefire:test -f /tmp/pom123.xml -DignoreMissingTests -Dtest=MyTest#case

or similar. Compared to using `javax.tools.JavaCompiler` this is a bit safer still, since even POM misinterpretations by the IDE would only affect editor functions, not test runs; and I think the overhead would be modest. (Maven CoS already runs `mvn`.)

TBD what is best for (managed or freeform) Ant- or Gradle-based builds, but this reinforces the notion that the project type can keep CoS functionality closer to the build system.

As far as I can tell, the application launchers (either "netbeans" or "app" for the platform applications) compute things like userdir and cachedir locations, process etc/<name>.conf and etc/<name>.clusters, etc. The "app" launchers is I think as the "netbeans" launcher, just not referring to only "netbeans".

I guess it might have some (historical) reason... For me having an 'ide' launcher makes sense as perhaps we need to search for `javac` or something IDE-specific. A generic launcher for the bare platform or platform-apps would also make sense. The 3rd one... not so sure.

But I don't want to insist. The code looks good to me.

So, if somebody could test it on Windows we should be fine.

Note that I would still very much like to be able to build it with Docker. I need to tweak some things for a Docker build so it would be nice if we could rearrange things for Docker to work out of the box.

If you look at my patch https://github.com/emilianbold/incubator-netbeans/commit/96ce9f36cb1e104df0cb61c880272432912f527d , particularly build-with-docker.sh, I am first copying o.n.bootstrap/launcher/windows/ and ide/launcher/windows into the apisupport.harness/windows-launcher-src/ subtree so Docker doesn't have to swallow the whole NetBeans source tree.

Having these 3 launchers grouped differently might also make more sense. I wonder if we could use symbolic links inside git itself?

@geertjanw Please refer the attached image demonstrating the new logo placed on the start page. would it be okay to amend the PR? 
![nbspv2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11485426/41218014-54755cce-6d77-11e8-9f58-f6aa223bd4a2.png)
Yes, please do.

> What we could do is to create a link to netbeans-vm.apache.org with appropriate parameters in the Start Page, have them logged in netbeans-vm.apache.org and then redirect to netbeans.apache.org.

-1 to hardcoding any links to the VM in the IDE.  My suggestion with the other URLs was to use the /nb path, and I suggest we do the same here - eg. `https://netbeans.apache.org/nb/welcome/`. We can redirect via the VM to collect stats, moving to another solution later if that proves unviable, without needing to push URL changes to the IDE.

I agree with your assessment. I forgot, that, that file can and should be discussed. My gut feeling also was, that the file use not of much use and does not contain relevant information. In this PR I already removed the cglib NOTICE file and rethinking it I, I would also remove the jaxws notice file. The contents has indeed no value (not even referencing the product itself), so from a legal perspective I would argue, that we don't loose anything. I'll update this tonight.

this is for Netbeans,
 **ide** seems ok too. I put it in place at netbeans / bin and netbeans launch with good jdk.

I have not idea for this one, this executable is located in platform/lib 
 **o.n.bootstrap/launcher/windows** is missing **"lib/nbexec.dll"** at runtime. I guess the **"lib/"** must be removed on the -DNBEXEC_DLL parameters for nbexe64.exe and nbexec.exe to act as before

I pushed an updated changeset. I looked again into the jaxws zip and checked maven central. The artifacts present in the zip are also available from maven central. Having these separated, allows us to grab them from central and attribute the licenses cleaner.
This also revealed, that parts of the dependencies were in fact CDDL-1.0 (they are from the Sun days).
The three issues targetting jaxws were folded into one commit, as the changes can't be separated meaningfully.
Can we merge this now?

With the ICLA in place I think there is no reason to not merge...

So +1 from me

Sven

I pushed three more commits into this branch (only new commits):
- the spring jars indeed hold a notice, this is now present
- testng indeed contains MIT licensed jquery and jcommander holds a NOTICE file (if you dig in the repository, in the distribution it is missing)
- winp might be discussable. Instead of patching winp, I switched to a maintained version (https://github.com/kohsuke/winp). The libraries code today is very similar to the state after patching (modulo a few years of fixes), so I think this is save. The API is stable (checked with ``japi-compliance-checker`). Part of the winp problem was, that the license integration code is not prepared for files showing up at build time (winp was build from source) and not coming from the normal download route.

> testng indeed contains MIT licensed jquery and jcommander holds a NOTICE file (if you dig in the repository, in the distribution it is missing)

It feels like we are somehow going above and beyond our duty if we not only inspect the 3rd party release but look into the repository, etc.

The libraries code today is very similar to the state after patching (modulo a few years of fixes), so I think this is save. The API is stable (checked with ``japi-compliance-checker`). 

It would be nice to have this a separate PR.
Can me merge this?
I am guessing you are handling the modification of irrelevant code in a different branch then?
Yes

A point outside the PR itself: I think we should try to keep modifications to a minimum and active upstream releases should IMHO be preferred.
The patch lacks reasoning, so it is difficult to reason what was the reason it was introduced. I guess it introduced to fix a bug in an old version and then noone checked if it was fixed upstream.
Looks good - feel free to merge. I would also cherry-pick it into master.

Yes, of course, it's good to use upstream versions and only patch if necessary.

The history of the patch is convoluted.

It seems to me that initially it added the DDL_TARGET system property: https://github.com/emilianbold/netbeans-releases/commit/96cb331b988290db870e35450f5fcec0cdf6d74f#diff-ac12f5b0fbc0ffeb077ce213ec649449

And this is something winp still has: https://github.com/kohsuke/winp/blob/master/src/main/java/org/jvnet/winp/Native.java#L147

But then they had a memory leak https://netbeans.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=180915 so they got rid of that system property and expressly ignore it: https://github.com/emilianbold/netbeans-releases/commit/77d8d691e17a546d2080b4a9e854f5240aff1431#diff-ac12f5b0fbc0ffeb077ce213ec649449

Now, I suspect that we might still get memory leaks with the current winp?

Maybe we have to clear the system property before calling winp?

We would need to test this on Windows before using the upstream version, see if #180915 still holds.

I think the MIT license part is in-line with the other parts of netbeans. If we change it, that can be done later.

**For the patch:**
My interpretation is different (in fact the system property is used before and after patching, just differently):

It is visible in the current form of the patch:
https://github.com/apache/incubator-netbeans/blob/master/extexecution.process/external/winp.patch#L23

From my interpretation the patch changes the usage of the `winp.folder.preferred` system property. Before the patch the property changed the `jarFile` variable, afterwards it changes the `dllFile` variable. The patch is sensible, as the location of the extracted dll (this is held in `dllFile`) can so be adjusted through a system property. And this would also explain the memory inflation, if the dll is loaded multiple time with different names.

The current winp code shows exactly the fixed behavior.  The source if searched here:
https://github.com/kohsuke/winp/blob/master/src/main/java/org/jvnet/winp/Native.java#L163
and the target is determined here:
https://github.com/kohsuke/winp/blob/master/src/main/java/org/jvnet/winp/Native.java#L148

You can run through the `extractToStaticLocation` method as often, as you want, it will only extract the file once, as the target location is only depended on the passed in URL and that is the URL of the embedded DLL, that does not change at runtime.
Seems OK.

The patch looks good.

I dislike these JARs that come with a mix of licenses.

I would prefer we have some structure here.

Here's an idea: instead of adding a new file 'Apache-2.0-smack' we should break up that into it's parts 'Apache-2.0' + 'BSD-jsch' + 'MIT-indiana' (not sure if it's really MIT, but as an example doesn't matter) and then have some way to declare this mix in the 'License:' header.

Maybe the '+' operator could have special meaning, instead of being part of the file? And it's parsed differently by the ant task?

Or maybe we create multiple files: we create 'BSD-jsch' and 'MIT-indiana' and also the 'full' file 'Apache-2.0+BSD-jsch+MIT-indiana' which is just a concatenation of those?

My idea being about structure but also about underlining true 'variants' of a license versus files that are covered by a bundle of multiple licenses. So a file MIT-xyz would be a variation of MIT while MIT+BSD is the license covering a JAR which has a mix of MIT and BSD licensed code.

Does this make sense? (We can move all this discussion in a separate thread on dev@ or something)

+1 for the patch

PS: Travis seems to fail due to low disk space?

Man, language!

Thank you for the review Emilian. The unittest failed, because there were whitespace issues in the license files (found it in the raw travis logs, looking for "BUILD FAILED"). The problem was locally reproduceable (I just overlooked the report).

I pushed a fixed changeset and will merge now.

So, I agree the call to importFQNs looks suspicious. Reema, what happens if that's removed altogether? I see the references to the moved class are rewritten using QualIdents (which should automagically resolve imports), so these shouldn't(?) need importFQNs. (The call to importFQNs in createNewFileForType seems fine, of course.)

My apologies, I meant that in a "Hey, you broke this thing, fix it!" way. I would have gone with poke, but people tend to ignore pokes.
It was a figure of speech.
If I remove this importFQNs call, imports for newly added inner class are not added. Investigating, this call seems to be required only for the moved class.

@jlahoda, @emilianbold I am looing at the "app" launcher sources. It derives  from "netbeans" launcher and sort of duplicates processing in "netbeans" launcher, but in places that interest me :-) it does not call super implementations, so ${DEFAULT_USERDIR_ROOT} etc placeholders are '''not''' replaced by "app" launcher - that's a bug I need to fix.

The "app" launcher adds processing of ${APPNAME} placeholder so that one .exe can serve for multiple platform-based application.
This can be merged, correct?
+1 for merging
0 for merging. As @vieiro said earlier, we have no way of doing stats this way afaik, which we could look to do with a unique inbound URL.  Depends how important that is?

I would like to at least have the logos, branding and URLs correct.

Metrics are somewhat unrelated and there's no need to block this until we figure it out.

> Metrics are somewhat unrelated and there's no need to block this until we figure it out.

Agreed!  Hence explicitly changing my -1 to 0. :smile:  Mind you, this might mean we couldn't figure out the metrics question until the next release (that's the pro of having unique URL's, although we might be able to so something with user agent instead).

After some thoughts ... are there some reasons why the "app" launcher diverges from the "netbeans" so much ? There also are some corner cases in NB's launcher which are not handled by "app" launcher.
 For example: 
* `HOME` token has different meaning on Windows and *NIX: on Windows, $HOME is replaced by `AppData` or `LocalAppData`; on UNIXes, HOME is ... well ;) home. The "netbeans" launcher uses the same (CSIDL_DESKTOP) for both cases.
* `DEFAULT_USERDIR_ROOT` is not procssed by "app" launcher, which invokes nbexec.dll without `--default_userdir_root`. This may cause issues if an  upgrade mechanism  similar to NetBeans is used (I do in my app).
* platform cluster can have '''absolute''' path in NB/*NIX, but not in "app". But both launchers support absolute paths for platform cluster on Windows.
* "app" launcher includes "platform" cluster in `--clusters` ? @JaroslavTulach - is it OK ?

shouldn't we synchronize the launchers a bit ?
+1 for merging too. If stats are required let's open a new JIRA for that.

The more processing can, @sdedic, be shared in `nbexec`, the better. The `netbeans` launcher is more advanced, as it was used more extensively - e.g. by a real product. The `app.exe` is just a demo toy, good for starting, but not sufficient for real production. The unsaid assumption was that once people need real launcher, they copy the source code and do what they want. There is however no reason for not enhancing the `nbexec` to work better for both `netbeans` as well as `app.exe` launches. If you can find the right abstractions, please go on and enhance `nbexec`.
